conclusion: The processes A→B and C→D are isothermal, meaning temperature T remains constant.
The number of molecules colliding with the wall per unit area per unit time depends on the number density n and the average speed of the molecules.
For an ideal gas, the number density n is inversely proportional to the volume V (n ∝ 1/V).
In the isothermal process C→D, the volume V changes while the temperature T remains constant.
As we move from state C to state D, the volume V increases because C→D is an expansion process.
Therefore, the number density n decreases because n ∝ 1/V.
Since the number density n decreases from state C to state D, the number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time also decreases.
